But ever the same — prompt, patient, and resolute, he moved among us, a model soldier, inspiring the faithful and shaming the singgish, seldom by precept, but always by example.
Death could not find such a man unprepared.--At every call his response was "ready," and we doubt not his answer to the final summons was the same.
Brave, yet amiable; gifted, yet modest; generous, yet just; "pure in life and upright in conversation." Thrice happy they who, when the last account be rendered, can present a record so free from stain or blemish?
Few have fallen in this coutest to whom life presouted a prospect more alluring.
He was barely twenty-four years of age when he was called away from the scenes of earth.
Called to the bar two years ago, his intelligence, energy, and devotion to his profession, gave promise of a brilliant and honorable career; but he could not remain in his office while his brethren were in the field, and at the first blast of the bugle he forsook his studies for the sword.
He returned to his home but once, and then on a holy and joyful mission.
In February he was wedded to her to whom his troth had been plighted, and giving but a few bright, brief days to love, tore himself away and hurried back to the scene of action.

lg.l: "Nor wife, nor friends, nor sacred home,

div4.p:
Alas! who shall intrude on the sanctity of her grief?
who dare attempt to console the young and lovely bride who, with amiles and tears, sent him forth a few short months ago to fight his country's battles?
yet "Time, the great comforter, shall bring healing on his wings, " and hereafter, when the clouds of war shall have cleared away, and a free people shall peacefully enjoy the independence they have won, all who loved him will recall, not only with grief and mourning, but with pleasure and with pride, the memory of him, the young, the brave, the gifted, who laid his life a sacrifice on the allar of our liberties.

lg.l: None knew thee but to love thee,
None named thee but to praise."

div4.p: [*] A Comrade.
Killed, in the battle of the Seven Pines, on the 31st May, J. F. Francis, Sergeant-Major of the 17th Virginia regiment.

The deceased was a native of Fauquier county, Va., and a practicing lawyer in the town of Leesburg.
When the first call was made for volunteers to defend his native State, he nobly responded by shore fering his musket and taking his position in the ranks of the Loudoun Guard.
Possessed of rare personal courage, gentle and unpretending in his manners, perfectly unselfish, an educated gentleman, and a true Christian, he fell whilst doing his duty in a noble cause, leaving a widowed mother and large circle of friends to mourn his untimely end. [*] A.

div3.head: Navy Department,
div3.p: General Orders.
A Board, composed of the following officers, will convene at Richmond, on the 25TH instant, for the examination of Acting Midshipmen of the Navy.
Flag-Officer George N. Hollins, President.
Commander R. D. Thorburn, Members.
Commander Chas. H. McBlair, Members.
Lieutenant Julian Myers, Members.
Lieutenant Wm. H. Parker, Members.
The following will be the order and subjects of examination:

list.head: Examination of the 1st class.
list.item:
1.
Navigation.--Day's Work, Time Light Latitude by Meridian alt, and use of Sextant.

2. Seamanship.--Rigging, Furling Salls, Reeling, sending up and down top-gallant and royal yards, Stowing Hold, Working Anchors and Chains.
General questions on.

3.
Mathematics.--Solution of plane and sphr.
triangles, Descriptive Astronomy, Surveying.
General questions on.

list.head: Ordnance Manual.
list.item:
4.
Gunnery.--Hardee's Light Infantry Drill (company); Field Howitzer Drill (Parker's). General questions on.

list.head: Examination of second class.
list.item:
1.
Navigation.--Day's Work., Latitude by Meralt.; Reading and adjusting Sextant.
General questions on.

2.
Seamanship.--Rigging, Furling Sails, Reefing, Sending up and down top gallant and royal yards.
General questions on.

3.
Mathematics.--Plane Trigonometry (solution of plane triangles); Mensuration of plane surfaces.
General questions on.

4.
Gunnery.--Manual of Small Arms; Practical Gunnery.
Questions on.

5.
History and Physical Geography.--General questions on.

list.head: Examination of Third class.
list.item:
1.
Mathematics.--Arithmetic and Algebra, to Equations of the 2d degree.

2. Gunnery.--Manual of Small Arms; Exercise of Great Guns.
Questions on.

list.head: Examination of Fourth class.
list.item:
1.
Must be able to read and write well.
3. Perform the various operations of the Primary Rules of Arithmetic, viz: Numeration and the Addition, Subtraction, Multiplication and Division of whole numbers.

div3.p: Acting Midshipmen on and off duty in Virginia and North Carolina will appear before the Board and hold themselves in readiness for examination.

After concluding the examination in this city, the Board will adjourn to meet in Savannah, Ga., Mobile, Ala., and at the Headquarters of the Naval Forces on the Mississippi river, and its tributaries; and all Acting Midshipmen on duty at those stations, and those not on duty within reach of those stations will hold themselves in readiness to appear before the Board when it meets.
div3.closer:
S. R. Mallory,
je 25--nod3t Sec'y of the Navy.

div3.head: Two hundred and Seventy dollars reward.
div3.p: --Left Magnolia last night, without the least cause, the following negroes:
Jefferson, 35 to 40 years old, ginger-bread color, medium height, stout built, of good address, very intelligent and artful.

Fox, who calls himself Ben Quarles.
about 25 years old, black, with white teeth, which he often shows with a grin when spoken to, is tall, and had some years ago a whitlow on one of his thumbs, believed the left.
These negroes belong to me, and are well acquainted on the Chickahominy, both above the Meadow Bridges and ten miles below.
Oscar, about 25 years old, below the medium size, black, rusty looking, and answering questions with an indifference almost amounting to stupidity.
Jim, also under the medium height, black, about 18 years old, with a round and plump face.
These were hired from Redwood & Keach, and belong to Mr. Chilton, of Lancaster, Va.

Joshua, a boy about 16 years old, black, with large eyes, and hair closely shaved.
Hired of Hector Davis, of Richmond.

My own negroes had a variety of clothing, but will probably put on soldiers' old clothes, which have been very plenty of late near me. There is no sort of doubt they are alming for the Yankee camps, and will probably attempt to cross the Chickaherainy near Meadow Bridges.

I will pay one hundred dollars each for the delivery to me, or for securing in any jail in Virginia so that I get them again, of Jeff, and Fox, and ten dollars each for Oscar and Jim, and am authorized by Mr. Davis, agent, to offer fifty dollars, in like manner, for Joshua.
N. F. Bowe.
Magnolla, June 24, 1862. je 25--3t*

div3.head: One hundred dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway, from the American Hotel, on Monday, the 9th inst., my negro boy William, who calls himself William May. Said boy is about 20 years old; five feet ten inches in height; of a bright ginger-bread color; very pleasant address, and neat appearance.
He was raised on the estate of the late Wm. G. Overton, of Hanover, and may be endeavoring to escape to the enemy in that vicinity.
I will give the above reward for his apprehension and delivery to me in Petersburg, or $75 if delivered to Messrs. J. L. Carrington & Co., American Hotel, Richmond, Va.
je 25--6t. Edmund G. James.
Whig, Examiner and Enquirer copy three times.

div3.head: Sixty dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from the subscriber, about the 10th of March, a negro boy, William, and on the 17th of June, Abram.
William is 21 years old, dark, copper colored, with thick lips and bushy hair; is about five feet ten inches high, with no special marks recollected, except a rupture.
Abram is black; 17 years old; stontly built; round face, and, pleasing countenance; about five feet five or six inches high, and has a very large scar from vaccination, and possibly two. Fifty dollars will be given for William if taken out of the county, or $10 for William or Abram each if taken in the county, and returned to me, or secured so that I get them.
Martin James, Lock Lomond P. O.,
je 25--d1aw6w* Goochland county, Va.

div3.head: Twenty-five dollars reward.
div3.p:
--My boy, Ben, left me on 7th inst., at camp near Dr. Garnett's house.
He is a stout, heavy-built man; about five feet seven inches high; 35 years of age; several teeth out in front; weighs about 160 pounds, is of black complexion; has heavy lips, and small whiskers on the chin.
I will pay the above reward for his delivery to me in camp, or for his apprehension and detention in some Richmond jail.
John C. Fizer,
je 19--5t* Lieut. Col. 17th Miss. Reg't.

On the 1ST day of June, a mulatto boy, named Bor, left the 3d Alabama Regiment, a short time before the battle of the Seven Pines, carrying with him a carpet bag full of clothes.--The boy was hired in Richmond, while passing through, and has not yet returned.
I have forgotten the name of his master.
Any information of him or the carpet bag will be suitably rewarded.--Address W. P. Vandercer, Alabama Depot, on Main street, above 8th.
je 18--6t*
